Just Updated

Hard Reset: Exile continues the original story.
Follow Major Fletcher into the Barrens - dangerous lands beyond the last human city of Bezoar, where our hero will meet new foes and make new friends. Get ready for more machine madness!
Hard Reset: Exile features:

  • Five new levels outside Bezoar
  • Four new enemy types
  • New boss fight
  • Two new survival maps
  • Additional achievements
Hard Reset: Exile is Free to owners of Hard Reset.

READ MORE

About This Game

In the only remaining human city of Bezoar, Major Fletcher, an Army Combat Veteran and soldier of the CLN, is dragged into a conflict between two of mankind's greatest enemies. He is to discover that nothing is what it seems to be.
Hard Reset is an action-packed, single-player shooter for the PC. With over-the-top destruction, loads of enemies, great weapon variety and a beautifully realized cyberpunk setting, Hard Reset is sure to shake up the shooter scene.

Key features:

  • A haunting cyberpunk / dark sci-fi setting
  • Fast-paced, old-school shooter gameplay
  • Hordes of enemies to destroy
  • Epic boss fights
  • A deep, experience-based weapon upgrade system
  • High-fidelity graphics with full dynamic lighting
  • Extensive use of physics and dynamic environments
READ MORE

System Requirements

    Minimum:
    • OS: Windows XP/Vista/7
    • Processor: 2.5 GHz Intel Pentium 4 / AMD Athlon 64
    • Memory: 2 GB
    • Hard Disk Space: 4 GB free hard drive space
    • Video Card: 512 MB NVIDIA GeForce 8800GS / ATI Radeon HD 3870 or better
    • DirectX®: DirectX 9.0c
    • Sound: DirectX Compatible
    Recommended:
    • OS: Windows XP/Vista/7
    • Processor: Intel Quad Core 2.3 GHz / AMD Phenom II x4 2.5 GHz
    • Memory: 3 GB
    • Hard Disk Space: 4 GB free hard drive space
    • Video Card: 512 MB NVIDIA GeForce 9800 GT / ATI Radeon HD 4870 or better
    • DirectX®: DirectX 9.0c
    • Sound: DirectX Compatible

Maximum Player
1,059 products in account
73 reviews
Recommended
17.0 hrs on record
Posted: October 11
If you have painkillers and are serious as Sam was, then you will like Hard Reset. So basically you are fightning with machines. There are two kind of weapons: assault rifle and energy gun - it seems small but both have 5 configurations so assault rifle can transform into combat shotgun, grenade launcher, proximity mine and rpg. Energy weapon have plasma rifle, shock blaster, railgun, homing projectiles and electric mortar with slowing field. In addition most weapons have alternate fire mode. Hard Reset is challenging, foes are quick and deadly even the smallest one which will swarm player with maximum ferocity like ants. The bigger ones like charger will rush towards you and knock out every obstacles with ease. But still there are much tougher guys... they fire homing missiles with enormous splash damage that hits player even when under cover. Nice music and awesome explosion effects included. Recommend stamp.

Was this review helpful? Yes No Funny
11 of 14 people (79%) found this review helpful
kschang77
920 products in account
140 reviews
Recommended
14.2 hrs on record
Posted: August 9
Hard Reset is one of those old-fashioned shooter games... first person, no cover, no blind shoot, it's circle strafe and lots and lots of weapons. The plot is simple: You're Fletcher, working for "The Corporation" holding the perimeter of Bezoar city against incursion of killer robots from the outside. When a breach in Sector 6 happened, you're the closest unit to respond, and you must defeat the robot minions, from small swarmers (size of dogs) to gorillas (they charge you, hard), to shooters and more. There are 4-12 secrets per level for you to discover. Some are quite visible, but you have no idea how to get to (some require strategic demolition of certain walls, just like Doom).

The plot has a couple twists and the voice acting... well, falls to the cliche at times. But the cutscnes are rendered in comic book style (albeit with sprite animations) to make for a unique look.

Another uniqueness to the game is plethora of environment kill objects, i.e. the proverbial 'exploding barrel', except in this game, they are all over the place. Explosive gas containers, barrels, high voltage fans, trash collectors, heaters on walls, they all explode or zap everything around them for a few seconds when hit. And you get extra points for using enviro-kills rather than your own ordnances.

Your guy gets three area of upgrades... body, projectile gun, and energy gun. Each area has 5 items that can be purchased / upgraded, and each item can have up to 2 additional upgrades. You come with plasma (for energy) and rifle (for projectile), as well as simple shields (i.e. you have 1 of each). As you advance, and collect N.A.N.O. the currency, whcih are "yellow/gold" in the game, you can eventually spend them at upgrade machines to buy the upgrades.

Certain enemies are more vulnerable to certain types of weapons, so you'll need to switch things up a bit. The enemies are helpfully color coded to help you sort out which is which.

There are PLENTY of boss battles, but basically, defeat all the minions that rushes you, then when the boss starts glowing red on certain sections, shoot those sections. Those areas don't glow red until you defeat the minions, so you can't concentrate on the boss alone. There are probably several groups of these vulnerable points you need to destroy before you can destroy the boss, while its minions hound you.

And there were many many levels. When you die, you are sent back to the nearest autosave / checkpoint, with one death recorded against your accomplishments on this level. There are plenty of achievements, such as time spent, how much of the level's NANO did you gather, how many kills, how many envirokills, damage done, damage received, and so on.

There are some jumping puzzles, but nothing too dramatic. There is no crouch, so it's shoot only. Some secret areas requires extended attempts at jumping and running.

All in all, Hard Reset is an old fashioned shooter with a better than decent plot and lots of action, but the call for enviro-kills seem to go against the shooter philosophyit adopted. It however, is a lot of fun to play.
Read More

-K
412 products in account
13 reviews
Recommended
12.4 hrs on record
Posted: July 19
Beep-boop-beep-boop-BOOOM!!! Great graphics. Cool weapons. Terrible voice acting. Not a bad shooter overall. I will admit that I had to tone it down to 'easy' just to get halfway through it. Ever wish you could play Quake in a Blade Runner type of setting? This is the game for you.
After completing the entire game I can say that it's very challenging. Getting cornered by hordes of common enemies was unfortunately more damaging than the actual boss fights. While you do get a chance to lay waste to thousands of little robots utilizing a variety of weapons, there is very little variety in the enemies themselves. The only thing that really changes through the game are the weapon upgrades and environments. The included Exile DLC does introduce a few more enemies.
Overall, it's worth playing, especially if you're itching for an improved classic shooter that won't hold your hand.

Was this review helpful? Yes No Funny
2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
dux0r
800 products in account
70 reviews
Recommended
10.3 hrs on record
Posted: June 9
Flying Wild Hog are a developer I've learned to love because of their unrelenting old-school design philosophy. They hand you a variety of interesting and unique weapons, add in a no-nonsense upgrade system, then throw you into a well detailed and absolutely gorgeous world and throw large numbers of fairly challenging enemies at you to overcome until they turn you into a badass. Coming out a year before the equally awesome Shadow Warrior, Hard Reset is an arcadey, clunky first-person romp through a near-future, lightly-cyberpunk city that flew almost completely under the radar.

Highlights
Much like Shadow Warrior, Hard Reset is a game that puts everything together really well, and gives a strong level of immersion that's missing from most games these days. I caught myself feeling like I was a detective inside a Blade Runner movie, trying to figure out what was going on while fighting off hoards of robots and passing through grimy city streets under the classy neon embankments, which, at times, is a real pleasure.

* The Flying Wild Hog Engine was built specifically for this title and is absolutely gorgeous while still performing really well
* The production value is clearly high, and it feels a lot more solid and well designed than just about any other indie title
* Extremely good content updates and freely released DLC which adds to the game deserve special mention

Mistakes

The settings and characters for this game give a ton of possibility and are really a blank canvas. It's a shame then, that what could've been an extra special experience ended up being merely an above average game due to a very forgettable plot and story and Comic-book intro scenes and good voice acting help the world come alive, but don't add much to the story or suspense.

* Feels like a corridor shooter at times and tends to feel very samey towards the end, despite the wide variety of weapons and upgrades
* For an FPS, it has lacklustre boss fights and a forgettable ending purely because of the lack of consequence, again because of the story

Recommendations

Priced at £9.99/13.49€/$14.99 at the time of review and clocking in at 8 hours gameplay, and with all the new content being released for free, Hard Reset is good value. It's also routinely on sale for as little as $4.99 on Steam and $1.49 from various Indie Bundle retailers.

* There's a fantastic Developer Artbook with characters, landscapes and plenty of concept art which is definitely worth a look. Available for free from here
* There's a free demo available on the Steam Store Page below which gives a good feel for the title
